speaker: Viral image
vclaim: On Twitter, Alexandria Okasio Cortez says, "I see people rushing to fill their cars for this tornado at the gas station. This will not be a problem if they have electric cars. If the power's out for a week, how are they gonna get the gas? We must start planning to move forward and move forward."
date: stated on September 4, 2019 in a Facebook post:
title: No, the company didn't tweet about electric cars and hurricanes.
text: Before Hurricane Dorian continued northward towards Carolina, Florida drivers waited at long lines at gas stations before the expected storm arrived. In some cases, they abandoned their cars after they ran out of fuel. An article on 4 September on Facebook appears to show that the U.S. Republic of Alexandria Okasio-Cortez is using this moment to promote an initiative to reduce climate change - but it is a false image of its Twitter account. "I see people rushing to fill their cars for this tornado at the gas station" starts with what looks like a shot of Ocacio Cortez's tweeting. "That wouldn't be a problem if they had electric cars. If the power's out for a week, how are they gonna get the gas? We must start planning to move forward and move forward." This article, in which more than 2,600 people participated, was referred to as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misinformation in the broadcast of the news. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) It was published on January 25, 2021 in a video that says Bill Gates "at least 3 billion people must die" from this planet. By Daniel Funk: January 27, 2021, the picture had been in existence since at least August 31, when Sebastian Gorka, a former official of President Donald Trump's administration, asked on Twitter whether Ocacio Cortez had really tweeted that. "No," Okasio Cortez replied. We looked at her latest tweet, and we didn't see anything like the picture in Facebook. Nor have we seen this on the Politops website, whose effects have been removed by the tweeting of government officials. We're assessing this wrong Facebook post.
